newsitem.title: USA: Mexican immigrant leaves jail after 14 years.
newsitem.headline: Mexican immigrant leaves jail after 14 years.

text.p: A Mexican immigrant jailed for almost 14 years on death row in a Texas prison for allegedly killing a policeman began on Wednesday his return trip to Mexico and freedom.

U.S. Immigration and Naturalisation Service (INS) agents accompanied Ricardo Aldape Guerra in a blue sedan as they took off from Houston to Brownsville, Texas, on the U.S.-Mexico border 300 miles (480 km) to the southwest.
Aldape Guerra, who came to the United States illegally in 1982, was whisked away by the INS as soon as he was released from Harris County Jail on Wednesday morning.
"I never committed any crime," he told Mexico's Televisa news network on Wednesday.
The Mexican government had a plane waiting to fly him home to Monterrey, Mexico, but an INS spokeswoman said Aldape Guerra would be treated like any other illegal immigrant and driven to the border.

His family and Mexican officials followed the INS vehicle in a van. At Brownsville, Aldape Guerra was to cross a bridge on the Rio Grande into Matamoros, Mexico, where he was to finally board a plane for his home city of Monterrey, officials said.
Mexican authorities were not sure where Aldape Guerra would cross the border but promised to have a plane ready to fly him to Monterrey in Nuevo Leon state, just two hours' drive from the border.
Mexican radio and television stations, always eager for stories about Mexicans suffering at the hands of their northern neighbour, made his impending return their top story.
Aldape Guerra's legal nightmare ended after Harris County District Attorney Johnny Holmes said on Tuesday he would drop the murder charge against him and not seek a new trial.
Holmes told reporters that a judge's decision earlier this week to throw out six key prosecution witnesses for lack of credibility had made it impossible to retry the case.
Aldape Guerra, now 35, was convicted in October 1982 and sentenced to death for the killing of Houston police officer James Harris during a routine traffic stop.

Aldape Guerra contended from the beginning that an acquaintance, Roberto Carrasco Flores, shot Harris. In 1994, U.S. District Judge Kenneth Hoyt ordered a new trial because he said police had intimidated witnesses into identifying Aldape Guerra as the shooter and prosecutors, in their zeal to avenge a cop's death, had manipulated evidence to get a conviction.

But Aldape Guerra, who had been within hours of execution on several occasions, remained on death row until last August when a federal appellate court upheld Hoyt's decision. He was moved to Harris County jail to await a new trial.
Defence attorney Scott Atlas told reporters before Aldape Guerra left jail that his client was "too emotional" to speak to the press.
"He said 'This is like starting my life all over again. I want to be with my loved ones. I'm just not ready to talk to the press yet,'" Atlas said.

Aldape Guerra left the jail in a vehicle with tinted windows that made him barely visible to a media horde waiting outside. But earlier he had smiled and waved from a second-floor window as he drank coffee with his lawyers.
Mexican consulate spokesman Mauricio Garcia said Aldape Guerra had expressed one wish as he awaited his release. "He's very anxious to eat some Mexican food," Garcia said.
